Guess what? The first amendment as it is actually written and intended does not guarantee or establish our rights in the matters enumerated, such as freedom of speech or assembly. These certainly are important principles to stand up for and defend. In fact, they were already held, which is the reason for the ammendment in the first place.
 
 The first amendment simply projects these rights from modification and restriction by congress, and therefore only by the federal government. For protection from elsewhere we have to look to our respective state constitutions, appropriate state legislation, and our own willingness to stand up for the rights of others.
 
 Debates can be made over each of the provisions in the 1st amendment, which I will hold off on, at least for the time being.
 
 Cheers

 The real 10th amendment
 
 "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people."
 
 First note "to the people". Just because the Constitution doesn't specifically outlaw something doesn't mean you can. Especially since there are also other laws which matter other than the Constitution. But for example no law says you can't kill someone by stabbing them in the head, right? So I can do it, right? Wrong. This is basically saying that if it isn't in the Constitution, the federal government can't claim that they can make laws about it.
 
 And besides that the 10th amendment really isn't talking about freedom, it's talking about powers, as in governing the country. This amendment is making sure the federal government isn't too powerful.
